title: How many species use natural objects as “tools”? - Quora

response.answer_text: All the ones Kenneth Coleman Stone mentions plus parrots, crows, sea otters and anecdotally there have been cases reported of both horses and goats holding a stick in their mouth and using it to scratch their backs. Tool use of a very simple kind can also occur in rats. I've seen photographs of the behaviour of a rat who lived in a smooth-sided tank. Her human hung a treat at the top of the tank where the rat couldn't reach it and then photographed the result. The rat rolled her food-bowl into the corner and stood on it - not high enough. Then she shoved her oblong nest box into the corner - still not high enough. So she stood back and looked at it and then turned her nest box around so that the long axis was pointing up the way, then climbed up and grabbed the treat. There was another case (no photographs in this case but I trust the owner) where two adult and one baby female rats lived in a cage which had a tunnel looping off it. The older rats were greedy and would take food from the young one. A treat was put into the cage while the two adults were sleeping in the loop of tunnel, and before eating the treat the younger doe gathered up a heap of bedding and used it to plug both ends of the tunnel to keep the adults confined while she had first crack at the treat.

In addition to what people have already listed, some arthropods use tools, including spiders (an orb web is a tool), digger wasps (they use small stones to tamp down the soil at their nest openings to conceal the nest from parasitic flies), and ant lions (which make sand funnels to trap ants and throw sand grains at them, which would be like throwing boulders on a larger scale).
